statement.p: Graph the equation \displaystyle{y}={3}{\left({4}^{{-{x}+{5}}}\right)}+{2}. You will select a point on the asymptote (only y coordinate matters); then you select two points on the exponential.

solution.p: Because \displaystyle{y}={3}{\left({4}^{{-{x}+{5}}}\right)}+{2} has \displaystyle+{2} at the end, the asymptote is at \displaystyle{y}={2}.
One convenient point is where \displaystyle-{x}+{5}={0} which is \displaystyle{x}={5}. Here \displaystyle{y}={5}.
A second convenient point is one left of 5, which is \displaystyle{x}={4}. Here \displaystyle{y}={14}
